@martinh we need to choose two different encryption keys one for dev and one for prod

also the following should be incorporated:
1. app "api knocking" (handshake) - 
- every request will create a dynamic api call (for example http://10.22.12.3/POS43DSD) 
- we will try to decrypt POS43DSD
- if decryption succeeds - we send 3 ip addresses to fetch data from
- if decryption fails we send "normal" news feed from regular website.

2. every request from FE app should deliver any unreachable IP addresses.

3. last resort weapon should be:
- github/gitlab/bitbucket repos containing encrypted ip address list
- gmail.com/outlook.com/tutanota.com imap containing encrypted ip address list

3. We should create push notification topic with all devices listed in it for batch messaging.

4. every access of the app should be preceeded with an http request to www.google.com (and similar websites) to ensure the device has internet connectivity.

5. in our api we should also be able to send app configuration - mainly - to activate background service fetching data from the API every 5-20 minutes - in case out push notification appid project is blocked by google.

6. we need to integrate with Shon's api:
- link generation api (to send users for first install
- get user details (bank, id etc...)

7. first installation should also be monitored and performed in batches - every batch should be generated with different destination IP addresses.

here is a dockerfile exapmle:
```
FROM nginx
COPY  /app/out/ /usr/share/nginx/html
# COPY build/web /usr/share/nginx/html
COPY nginx/default.conf /etc/nginx/conf.d
# COPY nginx/.htpasswd /etc/nginx/

RUN chown 1000:1000 -R /usr/share && chmod 755 -R /usr/share &&  chown 1000:1000 -R /var/cache && chmod 777 -R /var/cache && chown 1000.1000 -R /etc/nginx  && chown 1000.1000 -R /var/log/nginx && touch /var/run/nginx.pid && chown 1000.1000 /var/run/nginx.pid

```

ok so maybe we can perform an interim stage...
1. upon opening the url we create a session
2. backened can correlate this sessionis with the user identity
3. upon PWA installation the application can send the sessionid
4. backend will back-correlate the session id to the user id and send the userid back to the PWA
@martinh ?

the most important thing is that the link we send to the user will contain a unique identity which can be correlated with the user identity on a 1x1 way - then we can send back to the PWA user identity data to store for upcoming authentication

just to clarify - the only way we can identify a user is with this specially crafted link we send them to install the application.

this link will be available ONLY for one installation - after that the link is useless and if for example the user wants to install again or install on another device they will need to go through a procedure to create a new link.
so it is imperative we can identify the user upon installation of the app with MINIMAL user intervention (only click install...)

3. show session id on the PWA after installation

hey all - just got permission to see the design - I have a few comments:
1. I think that the space at the top of the app is too large - it is a lot of "wasted real estate"
2. I see that EVERY story looks like a blob post, we will have text only information, image only information, link only information, form for user data request  and Polls (maybe more types).
3. I think there should be an alert icon at the top for new incoming messages information and maybe even an indicator for read/unread messages/stories

In short, service worker is event driven, when the application is completely closed, it can only respond to a few events, push (for notification), fetch (not so important in this case), sync (this event can make some request and then save the data), but all these must be called by some server, like firebase, which should be also configured in the project so firebase knows where to send its requests
Yes but we want to have a periodic background fetch service is case fb stops working
periodicSync is another service worker feature, but its like limited by browser, it can only be activated minimum every 12 hours
And if u really mean "backgroundFetch" then thats not possible in pwa, it doesnt have support
Or background refresh

can you verify that please? I have done a non-PWA background service in flutter let try to find a solution for a background service that will work (even over 12h periods) but will be able to fetch without a PN
Even if it is pwa, it's environment is a browser alike, and it doesn't allow to run code by itself when its fully closed, when its not in RAM
we need a solution for it
Service worker allows to intercept request from third party apps for push notifications and sync
I am talking about a situation where PN does not work
I know we will have firebase so it can be manageable

https://pub.dev/packages/flutter_html_iframe


please verify:
1. click ability
2. on click in the iframe the user does not "leave" our application (as to prevent navigation issues)
3. check that the url is reachable before presenting it - if it is not reachable - show the user "under maintenance"
4. once this is done we should implement a mechanism to check if the url is reachable, if it is, we show the content - if it is not - use our mechanism to fetch a new url and notify the backend that the ifram url is not reachable

So, I made a lot of research, changing installed PWA's origin is not possible, it's like against security.
 
Inside PWA we can open "browser windows" that will be considered also "standalone", but on re-entering app from home menu, it will be the same old origin.
 
A workaround as it was with iPhones, it will be to show a message that "Origin is not accessible", and to explain how to uninstall, then redirect to "socapp-link" site, then install again. I know this is not the desired workflow, but we can't do what was not intended to work from browser perspective.

Thats a good idea, totaly agree, but I will leave the UniqID's mechanism. I will need it to monitor and manage tests in the automation framework
what is UniqID?

GitLab provides just a number for every new issue or child issue, and as we spredd the issues on more boards each board starts from begining (from 1) so without exstra "tactics" there will be a lot of same ID-s for different issues

basically everything needs to get through discussion and approvement, in order to adopt something. Creating unique ID for issue is a good idea, and we need to think of it fro different perspectives. From developement perspective its good to name branches according to issues they are facing at, eg `870-pwa-apple-installation-issue` and its okay to start numbers from 1 each time because each repository have unique set of branches
also up to group levels boards are uncorrelated, so if you have issue 1 on socapp its different from issue 1 on cashflow
